data.title: Spatial, Transform and Transform2D documentation tweaks
Unpredictable RayShape Area collision reporting (spooky)
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Fedora 25 with the latest 2.1 branch of godot.

**Issue description:**
If an area has a single RayShape and it's length is long enough to collide with an object that's reported, and using a script to set it's length low enough to no longer collide causes it to report no more collisions.

However. Doing the opposite reports no collisions for both states. This doesn't seem to be an issue with the physics server as setting the length to what it is already doesn't change the reported collisions.

I tried to track down the get_length() method in shape_sw.h and shape_sw.cpp but could only find get_length(). I'm not great with C++ and am not that experienced in maintaining godot but regardless I have very little idea what's causing the issue.


**Steps to reproduce:**
Github zip sharing isn't working for me but I've made a **very** minimal project repo (with instructions in the readme) linked below. Running it once and pressing return reports that the area is no longer colliding however if you change the RayShape in the editor to length 2 and change the script to set it to 5 it wont report the collision.

**Link to minimal example project:**
https://github.com/zavb074/RayAreaBugExample

changed the code font to Mononoki, looks better in low res screens, and seems to be a more fitting font.

data.title: Fix crash when no audio driver is available
data.body:
Fixes #1684.
This unifies the initialization logic for the audio drivers on a new function AudioDriverManager::initialize, which does pretty much the same as what was being done on the x11 code that I removed. So now if no driver is available godot will fall back to the dummy driver.

I've tested the changes on Windows, Linux and OS X. If anybody can help me testing this on the rest that I've changed (android, javascript, haiku and uwp) it would be great.

data.title: swapped up down shortcut for freelook (to fit unreal)
data.body:
@Zylann are you okay with that?

from:
https://docs.unrealengine.com/latest/INT/Engine/UI/LevelEditor/Viewports/ViewportControls/


Control | Action
-- | --
W¬†\|¬†Numpad8¬†\|¬†Up | Moves the camera forward.
S¬†\|¬†Numpad2¬†\|¬†Down | Moves the camera backward.
A¬†\|¬†Numpad4¬†\|¬†Left | Moves the camera left.
D¬†\|¬†Numpad6¬†\|¬†Right | Moves the camera right.
E¬†\|¬†Numpad9¬†\|¬†Page Up | Moves the camera up.
Q¬†\|¬†Numpad7¬†\|¬†Page Dn | Moves the camera down.
Z¬†\|¬†Numpad1 | Zooms the camera out (raises FOV).
C¬†\|¬†Numpad3 | Zooms the camera in (lowers FOV).

they also use e for up and q for down.

data.title: Fix inertia tensor update & Generic6DOFJoint & Simplify Basis::get_euler()
data.body:
This PR has evolved a bit. Here is a recap:

- Fix  a bug in the Generic6DOFJoint, angles were wrong because Basis::get_euler() uses a different convention than the previous method and YXZ convention was used while the XYZ is required.
- Fix a bug in the BodySW::_update_inertia_tensor() method. The Basis::scale() method was multiplying from the right, but now it multiplies from the left.
- Simplify the Basis::get_euler() method. Not sure if the implementation was causing problems in the Generic6DOFJoint, but now it is equivalent to the one that was written in the Generic6DOFJoint (It was borrowed from Bullet I think).

Not sure if point 3 can cause problems in other parts of the engine, I think it was @tagcup to introduce that change so I need his opinion.
This definitely fixes https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/11131 and likely other bugs

data.title: Create separate debug info files by default
data.body:
Now that we have a built-in stacktrace on a segfault it would be useful
to have debug information on debug_release builds so that bugreports can
include this information. Without this debug info we will still get
function names in the backtrace but not file location.

This commit will by default build all targets with minimal debug info
and then strip the information into separate files. On MacOS this is a
.dSYM file, on Linux/MingW this is a .debug file. MacOSX will
automatically load a dSYM file if it exists in its debugger. On
Linux/MingW we create a 'gnu debuglink' meaning that gdb and friends
will automatically find the debug symbols if they exist.

Existing workflow for developers does not change at all, except that we
now create two instead of one build artifact by default.

This commit also adds a 'debug_symbols' option to X11, MacOS, and MingW
targets. The default is 'yes' which corresponds to -g1. The alternatives
are 'no' (don't generate debug infos at all) or 'full' which runs with
-g2. A target=debug build will now build with -g3.

data.title: Android filesystem doesn't seem to create directory or text file
data.body:
Samsung Galaxy Tab A SM-T350 Android 6.0.1, Godot 2.1.3 or 2.1.4rc

Trying to write out data to a file, preferred to be in the Documents folder. However, I cannot figure out how to gain access to it. 
Using OS.get_system_dir(2) I get:
User directory: /storage/emulated/0/Download/ test_folder doesn't exist. /storage/emulated/0/Download/test_folder/test_file.txt opened.
fp_user error code: 12
/storage/emulated/0/Download/test_folder/test_file.txt written.

Yet there is clearly nothing written to the Download folder or the Documents folder.
According to the documentation I should be using 2 as the reference to Documents, but it doesn't return Documents, it returns Downloads. And 3 also returns Downloads. https://godot.readthedocs.io/en/stable/classes/class_os.html

Then I used 'user://' with no directory creation and I get:
User directory: user://
user://test_file.txt opened.
fp_user error code: 0
user://test_file.txt written

Yet I cannot find any test_file.txt anywhere.

All using code snip as I found it: https://godotengine.org/qa/6285/how-to-write-to-user-directory-in-android 

var dir = Directory.new()
var dir_name = "test_dir"
var filename = "test_file.txt"
var user_dir = "user://"
dir.open(user_dir)
print( "User directory: " + user_dir )
var fp_user = File.new()
var f_name = user_dir + filename;
var err = fp_user.open( f_name, File.WRITE )
print( f_name + " opened." )
print( "fp_user error code: " + str(err) )
fp_user.store_line( "This is a test file." )
print( f_name + " written." )
fp_user.close()

730d36f350 introduced introduced some code that indexes AudioFrame[3],
it is however defined as AudioFrame[3]. This increases the size to [4]

data.title: root node changing / moving / removing needs better UX
data.body:
This is a tracker/ summarisation issue of multiple issues all addressing the same issue.

 - #3723
 - #9363
 - #11217

possible solutions that were mentioned:
## 1 add right click option to add parent node 
```
 - clicked node (root)
   - child1
   - chidl2
```
->
```
- chooses node to add (root)
   - clicked node
      - child1
      - child2
```
 
## 2 drag and drop to top
```
- node1 (root)
   - node2
   - node3
```
-> dragging node 2 above node 1 (line should appear above node 1)
```
 - node2 (root)
   - node1
   - node3
```

## 3 just the option to add a node as the root

could be a simple checkbox in the add node window.
` add as root`
if not checked it adds the node as the root node.

data.title: Construct Variants from Reference properly in GDNative
Allow for multiple axis transformations
data.body:
**Issue description:**
In blender, you can hold shift to select multiple transformation options, to create combinations like this for instance:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/31744099/30380497-b51e9af6-9891-11e7-988a-4775b6383735.png)

Adding this would allow for the mouse pointer button to be removed (which is essentially just translate and rotate together). Speaking of which, it confused me at first, because I remembered seeing translate and rotate together, but once I'd switched to scale, I couldn't figure out how to get them both back.

data.title: Add a scaling axis
data.body:
**Issue description:**
Maybe I'm doing it wrong, but I can't seem to find the axis that allows you to resize an object on a single axis, like in Blender:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/31744099/30380142-b3fe8768-9890-11e7-9fbb-f524b53ae4f5.png)

I can only find one that scales the object equally on all axis:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/31744099/30380187-d1705da8-9890-11e7-8b0a-4fa441002ba3.png)

Which sure, is definitely useful, but a specific axis one would be great as well? If you wanted to save space or keep those buttons minimal, you could just add a surrounding circle to scaling axis, like you get with lights:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/31744099/30380301-27477d56-9891-11e7-8c33-4a8654bf8883.png)
and that would scale it equally on all axis, and leaving the arrows (or blocks for scaling) to handle the individual axis.

It would certainly be easier than trying to enter each one in the transform menu, I always forget to press enter and have to re-enter it a couple of times.

data.title: Give GUI input fields a "reset" option
data.body:
**Issue description:**
When you're messing around with settings, sometimes you just want to put something back to its default value, but you can't undo because you made some changes elsewhere that you don't want to revert.

I'd imagine it be like right clicking on the option, and clicking "default" from a dropdown, Blender is a good example:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/31744099/30380035-560fc0f4-9890-11e7-8d7b-046e390080b1.png)

data.title: SRC_COLOR undeclared in canvas_item shader
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Ubuntu 16.04
Godot 3.0 fe33ef5a1948af7c89a6d71de3580341cf2c0d6a
GPU: AMD RX 480 with AMDGPU driver

**Issue description:**
The 2D canvas_item shader:
```
shader_type canvas_item;

void fragment() {
	COLOR = mix(vec4(0,0,0,0),SRC_COLOR,sin(TIME));
}
```
on a sprite node crashed  with:

`ERROR: _gl_debug_print: GL ERROR: Source: Shader Compiler Type: Error ID: 2 Severity: High Message: 0:238(13): error: `m_SRC_COLOR' undeclared`

**Steps to reproduce:**
- Create a sprite node
- attatch a Shader material
- arratch a texture

- Write a shader that utilizes SRC_COLOR in any way
- Profit?

**Link to minimal example project:**
[src_color_example.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/1299358/src_color_example.zip)

`  print(get_slide_collision(0))`

and I get this on console:
`slide count: 1`

or am I doing something wrong?  the get_slide_count is the new get_collision_count, right? atleast it will return 0 count when my character is still on air dropping to ground.
